What are the chances that the O2 detected on the moon came along with the craft which landed in order to detect potential gasses?
The speed the moon travels coupled with a bare minimum gravitational force leads me to be suspicious of the source of the detected O2. I mean, we already know that if any ice on the moon melts, it is gone for good. Meaning it does not stick around to refreeze. That means both the hydrogen and oxygen leaves for open space, probably getting pulled back towards Earth if not the sun.
There is no plant life on the moon. Even if an oxygen molecule made it to the moon, how could it possible survive the direct, unfiltered sunlight long enough to be detected at any later time?
The detector(s) were made here on Earth where oxygen is prevalent. Same with any craft sent. That means an alien source of gasses which can potentially be detected. And since the gasses were Earth based, results would show the molecules detected came from Earth.
But the results do NOT determine when the molecules arrived. The detection is suspicious for many reasons. One of those reasons... the "dirt" the moon consists of. It is roughly 45% oxygen, largely bound to metals such as iron and even titanium if I remember chemistry correctly.
Not saying the detection was faulty. Just saying there is some legitimate doubt regarding source.

caption:

A fart can escape your jeans, but it can also Jeans escape. What does that mean? Well, it means that it's possible that you have farted on the moon. Molecules in our atmosphere are always bumping into each other. A collision can slow a molecule down, but it can also speed a molecule up. Astronomer James Jeans showed that a collision or a series of collisions can even accelerate a molecule in our atmosphere to earth's escape velocity. Under the right conditions, such a molecule can leave earth forever to be free, to roam the solar system. This process is called Jeans escape. It's why we found oxygen from earth on the moon. It and related mechanisms are why earth loses 3 kilograms of hydrogen every single second. And a human fart can be 50% hydrogen. So, whenever you bake an air muffin, you're reaching for the stars.
